snippet: The lawsuit says current and former executives and board members breached their fiduciary duty in their handling of allegations involving a Mexican subsidiary.
abstract: California State Teachers' Retirement System, one of the nation's largest pension plans, files a lawsuit accusing Wal-Mart's current and former executives and board members of breaching their fiduciary duty in connection with a bribery scandal at the retailer's Mexican subsidiary. Photos (M)a

byline.original: By STEPHANIE CLIFFORD; Gretchen Morgenson contributed reporting

lead_paragraph: One of the nation's largest pension plans filed a lawsuit Thursday accusing Wal-Mart's leadership of breaching its fiduciary duty in connection with a bribery scandal at the retailer's Mexican subsidiary. The pension plan, the California State Teachers' Retirement System, owns about 5.3 million shares in Wal-Mart, worth about $313 million. Although that is a small stake -- far less than 1 percent -- the suit was filed on behalf of Wal-Mart itself against people the pension plan identified as having failed in their duties to the company.

headline.main: Pension Plan Sues Wal-Mart Officials Over Failures
